fields.rmd:
# Project Results ```{r, echo=FALSE} library(ggplot2) library(pander) pie_chart <- function(data, x, y, title) { data[['label']] <- paste0(data[[x]], ' = ', round(data[[y]]), '%') data[['empty']] <- factor(0) pie <- ( ggplot(data, aes_string(x='empty', y=y, fill='label')) + geom_bar(stat='identity', width = 1) + labs(title=title, x='', y='') + theme_bw() + theme( axis.ticks.y=element_blank(), axis.text.y=element_blank(), axis.text.x=element_blank(), panel.grid.major.y=element_blank(), panel.border=element_blank() ) + coord_polar(theta='y') + guides(fill=guide_legend(title='')) ) return(pie) } respondents <- data if ("UrbanM4M" %in% names(respondents)) { urbanrespondents <- respondents[respondents$UrbanM4M == 1,] urbanmessage <- paste(nrow(urbanrespondents), " respondents were urban residents.") if(nrow(urbanrespondents)) { show_urban <- TRUE } else { show_urban <- FALSE } } else { urbanrespondents <- respondents urbanmessage <- "Note that all respondents were assumed to be urban residents." show_urban <- TRUE } cutoff <- 100 n <- nrow(respondents) warning_message <- n < cutoff density <- data.frame(Quintile=1:5) density$Percentage <- sapply(density$Quintile, function(i) { 100 * sum(respondents$NationalQuintile == i) / nrow(respondents) }) my_table <- data.frame( k=c(as.character(density$Quintile), 'Total'), v=c(density$Percentage, sum(density$Percentage)) ) names(my_table) <- c('Wealth quintile', 'Percentage of respondents') bottom_two <- sum(density$Percentage[density$Quintile %in% c(1, 2)]) ``` `r n` respondents have been interviewed. ```{r, echo=FALSE, results='asis'} if (warning_message) { cat(paste( 'We encourage you to consider your sample size when interpreting results. This sample of', n, 'may be small.' )) } ``` ## National quintile results
```{r, echo=FALSE, fig.width=4, fig.height=3} pie_chart(density, x='Quintile', y='Percentage', title='') ``` ```{r, echo=FALSE, results='asis'} pandoc.table(my_table, style='rmarkdown', round=1, keep.trailing.zeros=TRUE, justify='left') ```
These are the national quintile results for these respondents. These results indicate how your respondents compare to the national population. The table shows you the percentage of your respondents that were in each national wealth quintile. Quintile 1 is the lowest wealth quintile and quintile 5 is the highest wealth quintile. `r round(bottom_two)`% of your respondents were in the bottom two quintiles. This means that a relatively `r ifelse(bottom_two >= 40, 'large', 'small')` number of respondents were poor. For more information on interpreting wealth quintile results, [please click here](http://www.equitytool.org/wealth-quintiles/).
`r if (show_urban) '## Urban quintile results'`
```{r, echo=FALSE, fig.width=4, fig.height=3} density <- data.frame(Quintile=1:5) density$Percentage <- sapply(density$Quintile, function(i) { 100 * sum(urbanrespondents$UrbanQuintile == i) / nrow(urbanrespondents) }) my_table <- data.frame( k=c(as.character(density$Quintile), 'Total'), v=c(density$Percentage, sum(density$Percentage)) ) names(my_table) <- c('Wealth quintile', 'Percentage of respondents') bottom_two <- sum(density$Percentage[density$Quintile %in% c(1, 2)]) if (show_urban){ pie_chart(density, x='Quintile', y='Percentage', title='') } ``` ```{r, echo=FALSE, results='asis'} if (show_urban){ pandoc.table(my_table, style='rmarkdown', round=1, keep.trailing.zeros=TRUE, justify='left') } ```
`r paste(urbanmessage)` `r if (show_urban) 'These are the urban quintile results for these respondents. These are the results comparing your respondents to urban residents only. The table shows you the percentage of your respondents that were in each urban wealth quintile. Quintile 1 is the lowest wealth quintile and quintile 5 is the highest wealth quintile.'` `r if (show_urban) round(bottom_two)` `r if (show_urban) '% of your respondents were in the bottom two quintiles. This means that a relatively '` `r if (show_urban) ifelse(bottom_two >= 40, 'large', 'small')` `r if (show_urban) 'number of respondents were poor. For more information on interpreting wealth quintile results, [please click here](http://www.equitytool.org/wealth-quintiles/).'`
fields.name: Urban

fields.rmd:
# Project Results ```{r, echo=FALSE} library(ggplot2) library(pander) pie_chart <- function(data, x, y, title) { data[['label']] <- paste0(data[[x]], ' = ', round(data[[y]]), '%') data[['empty']] <- factor(0) pie <- ( ggplot(data, aes_string(x='empty', y=y, fill='label')) + geom_bar(stat='identity', width = 1) + labs(title=title, x='', y='') + theme_bw() + theme( axis.ticks.y=element_blank(), axis.text.y=element_blank(), axis.text.x=element_blank(), panel.grid.major.y=element_blank(), panel.border=element_blank() ) + coord_polar(theta='y') + guides(fill=guide_legend(title='')) ) return(pie) } respondents <- data if ("UrbanM4M" %in% names(respondents)) { urbanrespondents <- respondents[respondents$UrbanM4M == 1,] urbanmessage <- paste(nrow(urbanrespondents), " respondents were urban residents.") if(nrow(urbanrespondents)) { show_urban <- TRUE } else { show_urban <- FALSE } } else { urbanrespondents <- respondents urbanmessage <- "Note that all respondents were assumed to be urban residents" show_urban <- FALSE } cutoff <- 100 n <- nrow(respondents) warning_message <- n < cutoff density <- data.frame(Quintile=1:5) density$Percentage <- sapply(density$Quintile, function(i) { 100 * sum(respondents$NationalQuintile == i) / nrow(respondents) }) my_table <- data.frame( k=c(as.character(density$Quintile), 'Total'), v=c(density$Percentage, sum(density$Percentage)) ) names(my_table) <- c('Wealth quintile', 'Percentage of respondents') bottom_two <- sum(density$Percentage[density$Quintile %in% c(1, 2)]) ``` `r n` respondents have been interviewed. ```{r, echo=FALSE, results='asis'} if (warning_message) { cat(paste( 'We encourage you to consider your sample size when interpreting results. This sample of', n, 'may be small.' )) } ``` ## National quintile results
```{r, echo=FALSE, fig.width=4, fig.height=3} pie_chart(density, x='Quintile', y='Percentage', title='') ``` ```{r, echo=FALSE, results='asis'} pandoc.table(my_table, style='rmarkdown', round=1, keep.trailing.zeros=TRUE, justify='left') ```
These are the national quintile results for these respondents. These results indicate how your respondents compare to the national population. The table shows you the percentage of your respondents that were in each national wealth quintile. Quintile 1 is the lowest wealth quintile and quintile 5 is the highest wealth quintile. `r round(bottom_two)`% of your respondents were in the bottom two quintiles. This means that a relatively `r ifelse(bottom_two >= 40, 'large', 'small')` number of respondents were poor. For more information on interpreting wealth quintile results, [please click here](http://www.equitytool.org/wealth-quintiles/).
`r if (show_urban) '## Urban quintile results'`
```{r, echo=FALSE, fig.width=4, fig.height=3} density <- data.frame(Quintile=1:5) density$Percentage <- sapply(density$Quintile, function(i) { 100 * sum(urbanrespondents$UrbanQuintile == i) / nrow(urbanrespondents) }) my_table <- data.frame( k=c(as.character(density$Quintile), 'Total'), v=c(density$Percentage, sum(density$Percentage)) ) names(my_table) <- c('Wealth quintile', 'Percentage of respondents') bottom_two <- sum(density$Percentage[density$Quintile %in% c(1, 2)]) if (show_urban){ pie_chart(density, x='Quintile', y='Percentage', title='') } ``` ```{r, echo=FALSE, results='asis'} if (show_urban){ pandoc.table(my_table, style='rmarkdown', round=1, keep.trailing.zeros=TRUE, justify='left') } ```
`r if (show_urban) paste(urbanmessage)` `r if (show_urban) 'These are the urban quintile results for these respondents. These are the results comparing your respondents to urban residents only. The table shows you the percentage of your respondents that were in each urban wealth quintile. Quintile 1 is the lowest wealth quintile and quintile 5 is the highest wealth quintile.'` `r if (show_urban) round(bottom_two)` `r if (show_urban) '% of your respondents were in the bottom two quintiles. This means that a relatively '` `r if (show_urban) ifelse(bottom_two >= 40, 'large', 'small')` `r if (show_urban) 'number of respondents were poor. ,Q1,select_one Q1list,"Dans ce ménage, avez-vous : L'électricité ?",True,,"In this household, do you have (Referring to functioning hardware and equipment): Electricity?",${Q1_NAT},${Q1_URB},+
,Q2,select_one Q2list,Une télévision ?,True,,A television?,${Q2_NAT},${Q2_URB},+
,Q3,select_one Q3list,Un réfrigérateur ?,True,,A refrigerator?,${Q3_NAT},${Q3_URB},+
,Q4,select_one Q4list,Un abonnement à Canal?,True,,A subscription to Canal?,${Q4_NAT},${Q4_URB},+
,Q5,select_one Q5list,"Un réchaud ou une cuisinère, à gaz ou électrique?",True,,A gas or electric cooker or stove?,${Q5_NAT},${Q5_URB},+
,Q6,select_one Q6list,Un vidéo/lecteur CD/DVD?,True,,A video recorder or CD/DVD player?,${Q6_NAT},${Q6_URB},+
,Q7,select_one Q7list,Est-ce qu'un membre de votre ménage a un compte en banque ?,True,,Does any member of your household have a bank account?,${Q7_NAT},${Q7_URB},+
,Q8,select_one Q8list,D'où provient principalement l'eau que boivent les membres de votre ménage ?,True,,What is the main source of drinking water for members of your household?,${Q8_NAT},${Q8_URB},+
,Q9,select_one Q9list,Quel type de toilettes les membres de votre ménage utilisent-ils habituellement ?,True,,What type of toilet is usually used by members of your household?,${Q9_NAT},${Q9_URB},+
,Q10,select_one Q10list,Quel type de combustible votre ménage utilise-t-il principalement pour cuisiner ?,True,,What is the main type of fuel used for cooking in this household?,${Q10_NAT},${Q10_URB},+
,Q11,select_one Q11list,Quel est le matériau principal du sol de votre maison? ,True,,What is the main material of the floor of your house?,${Q11_NAT},${Q11_URB},
